Week 7 [16-23 Mar 2022]

Day 30 [16 Mar]

Question 49: Missing Number

Given an array nums containing n distinct numbers in the range [0, n], return the only number in the range that is missing from the array.

My solution:

1public int missingNumber(int[] nums) {
2    int n = nums.length;
3    int res = n * (n + 1) / 2;
4    for (int num:nums) {
5        res-=num;
6    }
7    return res;
8}
Remarks and Complexity Analysis:

  • It took me more time than it should have to solve this question in O(n) (~10 min). I had a confusion where I wondered if there is a data structure that permits O(1) deletion – there isn’t.

  • Time Complexity: O(n) where n=nums.length. Only one traversal across the nums array is required

  • Space Complexity: O(1).

Interesting aproach using XOR

public int missingNumber(int[] nums) {
    int xor = 0;
    for (int i = 0; i < nums.length; i++) {
        xor = xor ^ i ^ nums[i];
    }
    return xor ^ nums.length;
}

Bit manipulation isn’t my forte, but here goes my attempt at an explanation - xor is short for exclusive or (i.e. like regular or but 1 and 1 => 0). Hence, when we take int a and take the xor of itself - a^a – the result will be 0. As xor of 0 and any integer z is z, we can say that 0 behaves like an additive identity in our scenario. Hence, if we xor all integers from 0 to n and all integer elements of the nums array, we should be left with the one number that hasn’t been ‘cancelled out’ which is our result!

Remarks and Complexity Analysis:

  • Clever solution!

  • Time Complexity: O(n) where n=nums.length. Only one traversal across the nums array is required

  • Space Complexity: O(1).

Question 50: Invert Binary Tree

Given the root of a binary tree, invert the tree, and return its root.

My recursive solution:

 1public TreeNode invertTree(TreeNode root) {
 2    if (root!=null) {
 3        this.invertTree(root.left);
 4        this.invertTree(root.right);
 5
 6        TreeNode tempLeft = root.left;
 7        root.left = root.right;
 8        root.right = tempLeft;
 9    }
10    return root;
11}

Wondering if I should have implimented a helper function that returns void to make the code more deliberate/articulate.

My revised solution:

1public TreeNode invertTree(TreeNode root) {
2    if (root!=null) {
3        TreeNode tempLeft = root.left;
4        root.left = this.invertTree(root.right);;
5        root.right = this.invertTree(tempLeft);
6    }
7    return root;
8}
Remarks and Complexity Analysis:

  • Many recursive calls can cause overflow. Using a stack and while-loop can prevent this. Example provided below.

  • Time Complexity: O(n) where n=number_of_nodes. Every node is traversed once.

  • Space Complexity: O(1) - ignoring the implicit recursive calls.

Robust solution:

 1public TreeNode invertTree(TreeNode root) {
 2
 3    if (root == null) {
 4        return null;
 5    }
 6
 7    final Deque<TreeNode> stack = new LinkedList<>();
 8    stack.push(root);
 9
10    while(!stack.isEmpty()) {
11        final TreeNode node = stack.pop();
12        final TreeNode left = node.left;
13        node.left = node.right;
14        node.right = left;
15
16        if(node.left != null) {
17            stack.push(node.left);
18        }
19        if(node.right != null) {
20            stack.push(node.right);
21        }
22    }
23    return root;
24}

Question 51: Reverse Bits

Reverse bits of a given 32 bits unsigned integer.

My failed solution:

1public int reverseBits(int n) {
2    StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(String.format("%32s", Integer.toBinaryString(n)).replace(' ', '0'));
3    sb.reverse();
4    return Integer.parseInt(sb.toString(),2);
5}

Note

Fails because it tries to parse a number that would require 33 bits to store as a signed integer. It was foolish to approach this from a String manipulation approach as it requires lots of conversions.

Solution:

 1public int reverseBits(int n) {
 2    if (n == 0) return 0;
 3
 4    int result = 0;
 5    for (int i = 0; i < 32; i++) {
 6        result <<= 1;
 7        if ((n & 1) == 1) result++;
 8        n >>= 1;
 9    }
10    return result;
11}

Note

result <<= 1; shifts the bit-representation of result to the left by one unit. Then, if the last digit of the n is a 1 we append it to our result by adding 1. Then, we shift the n’s binary representation to the right by one unit to consider the next digit.

Remarks and Complexity Analysis:

  • Time Complexity: O(1) – loop will repeat a fixed number of times (i.e. 32)

  • Space Complexity: O(1)

Day 31 [17 Mar]

Question 52: Number of 1 Bits

Write a function that takes an unsigned integer and returns the number of ‘1’ bits it has (also known as the Hamming weight).

Note

Note that in some languages, such as Java, there is no unsigned integer type. In this case, the input will be given as a signed integer type. It should not affect your implementation, as the integer’s internal binary representation is the same, whether it is signed or unsigned.

In Java, the compiler represents the signed integers using 2’s complement notation. Therefore, in Example 3, the input represents the signed integer. -3.

My solution:

1public int hammingWeight(int n) {
2    int res = 0;
3    while (n!=0) {
4        res+=(n&1);
5        n>>>=1;
6    }
7    return res;
8}
Remarks and Complexity Analysis:

  • Quite similar to logic used in Question 51: Reverse Bits.

  • Wasted time struggling because I didn’t know the difference between >>> (Unsigned Right Shift Operator) and >> (Signed Right Shift Operator). We should be using the unsigned shift operator as specified in the question.

  • Time Complexity: O(1) there is a defined upper limit for the number of iterations as Java’s int is stored as 32-bit (i.e. 32 iterations).

  • Space Complexity: O(1)

Question 53: Subtree of Another Tree

Given the roots of two binary trees root and subRoot, return true if there is a subtree of root with the same structure and node values of subRoot and false otherwise.

A subtree of a binary tree tree is a tree that consists of a node in tree and all of this node’s descendants. The tree tree could also be considered as a subtree of itself.

My faulty solution:

 1private TreeNode findSubTreeRoot(TreeNode root, int strVal) {
 2    if (root==null) {
 3        return null;
 4    } else if (root.val==strVal) {
 5        return root;
 6    } else {
 7        TreeNode left = this.findSubTreeRoot(root.left, strVal);
 8        TreeNode right = this.findSubTreeRoot(root.right, strVal);
 9        if (left==null)  {
10            if (right==null) {
11                return null;
12            } else {
13                return right;
14            }
15        } else {
16            return left;
17        }
18    }
19}
20
21private boolean isSameTree(TreeNode root1, TreeNode root2) {
22    if (root1==null | root2==null) {
23        return (root1==null & root2==null);
24    } else if (root1.val!=root2.val) {
25        return false;
26    } else {
27        return this.isSameTree(root1.left, root2.left) & this.isSameTree(root1.right, root2.right);
28    }
29}
30
31public boolean isSubtree(TreeNode root, TreeNode subRoot) {
32    TreeNode subRootFound = this.findSubTreeRoot(root,subRoot.val);
33    if (subRootFound==null) {
34        System.out.println("Not FOUND");
35        return false;
36    } else {
37        return this.isSameTree(subRootFound, subRoot);
38    }
39}

161 / 182 test cases passed => didn’t handle the scenario of duplicate node values.

Second Attempt:

 1private TreeNode[] findSubTreeRoot(TreeNode root, int strVal) {
 2    if (root==null) {
 3        return new TreeNode[0];
 4    } else {
 5        TreeNode[] left = this.findSubTreeRoot(root.left, strVal);
 6        TreeNode[] right = this.findSubTreeRoot(root.right, strVal);
 7        if (root.val==strVal) {
 8            return ArrayUtils.add(ArrayUtils.addAll(left,right),root);
 9        } else {
10            return ArrayUtils.addAll(left,right);
11        }
12    }
13}
14
15private boolean isSameTree(TreeNode root1, TreeNode root2) {
16    if (root1==null | root2==null) {
17        return (root1==null & root2==null);
18    } else if (root1.val!=root2.val) {
19        return false;
20    } else {
21        return this.isSameTree(root1.left, root2.left) & this.isSameTree(root1.right, root2.right);
22    }
23}
24
25public boolean isSubtree(TreeNode root, TreeNode subRoot) {
26    TreeNode[] subRootFound = this.findSubTreeRoot(root,subRoot.val);
27    if (subRootFound.length==0) {
28        return false;
29    } else {
30        for (TreeNode candNode: subRootFound) {
31            if (this.isSameTree(candNode, subRoot)) {
32                return true;
33            }
34        }
35        return false;
36    }
37}

LeetCode doesn’t recognize ArrayUtils… why?

Solution

 1public boolean isSubtree(TreeNode s, TreeNode t) {
 2    if (s == null) return false;
 3    if (isSame(s, t)) return true;
 4    return isSubtree(s.left, t) || isSubtree(s.right, t);
 5}
 6
 7private boolean isSame(TreeNode s, TreeNode t) {
 8    if (s == null && t == null) return true;
 9    if (s == null || t == null) return false;
10
11    if (s.val != t.val) return false;
12
13    return isSame(s.left, t.left) && isSame(s.right, t.right);
14}
15
16// Another solution
17
18public boolean isSubtree(TreeNode root, TreeNode subRoot) {
19    if (isEqualTree(root, subRoot)) return true;
20    if (root == null) return false;
21    return isSubtree(root.left, subRoot) || isSubtree(root.right, subRoot);
22}
23
24private boolean isEqualTree(TreeNode root1, TreeNode root2) {
25    if (root1 == null || root2 == null) return root2 == root1;
26    return root1.val == root2.val && isEqualTree(root1.left, root2.left) && isEqualTree(root1.right, root2.right);
27}
Remarks and Complexity Analysis:

  • It was not a difficult question but I failed. And I believe the cause of the failure is the fact that I did not have a clear design in my head about the implementation before I went to coding it. Moreover, I did not consider the potential edge cases and various scenarios leading to a futile attempt to refactor my code after the ship has sailed.

  • Time Complexity: O(n*m) where n=num_of_nodes_of_main_tree and m=num_of_nodes_of_sub_tree as each node is traversed once.

  • Space Complexity: O(1)

Note

You can never plan enough!

Day 32 [18 Mar]

Question 54: 3Sum

Given an integer array nums, return all the triplets [nums[i], nums[j], nums[k]] such that i != j, i != k, and j != k, and nums[i] + nums[j] + nums[k] == 0.

Notice that the solution set must not contain duplicate triplets.

My solution after misunderstanding the question:

 1public void newTwoSum(Set<Integer> nums, int target, List<List<Integer>> res) {
 2    // List<List<Integer>> res = new ArrayList<>();
 3    Set<Integer> memo = new HashSet<>();
 4    for (int n:nums) {
 5        if (memo.contains(n)) {
 6            res.add(new ArrayList<Integer>(Arrays.asList(-target,n,target-n)));
 7        } else {
 8            memo.add(target-n);
 9        }
10    }
11}
12
13public List<List<Integer>> threeSum(int[] nums) {
14    List<List<Integer>> res = new ArrayList<>();
15
16    Set<Integer> negNums = new HashSet<>();
17    Set<Integer> posNums = new HashSet<>();
18    boolean zeroExists = false;
19
20    for (int n:nums) {
21        if (n==0) {
22            zeroExists = true;
23        } else if (n>0) {
24            posNums.add(n);
25        } else {
26            negNums.add(n);
27        }
28    }
29
30    // zero case
31    if (zeroExists) {
32        for (int posN: posNums) {
33            if (negNums.contains(-posN)) {
34                // List<Integer> tmp = new ArrayList<>(Arrays.asList(0,posN,-posN));
35                res.add(new ArrayList<Integer>(Arrays.asList(0,posN,-posN)));
36            }
37        }
38    }
39    // 1 pos, 2 neg case
40    for (int posN:posNums) {
41        this.newTwoSum(negNums,-posN,res);
42    }
43    // 1 neg, 2 pos case
44    for (int negN:negNums) {
45        this.newTwoSum(posNums,-negN,res);
46    }
47    return res;
48}

I did not read the test cases carefully and mistakenly thought that it was a requirement that the triplets are consisted of unique integers.

Note

Read the test cases and instructions carefully!

My solution:

 1public void newTwoSum(List<Integer> nums, int target, List<List<Integer>> res) {
 2    Set<Integer> memo = new HashSet<>();
 3    Set<Integer> done = new HashSet<>();
 4    for (int n:nums) {
 5        if (done.contains(n)) {
 6            continue;
 7        } else if (memo.contains(n)) {
 8            res.add(new ArrayList<Integer>(Arrays.asList(-target,n,target-n)));
 9            done.add(n);
10        } else {
11            memo.add(target-n);
12        }
13    }
14}
15
16public List<List<Integer>> threeSum(int[] nums) {
17    List<List<Integer>> res = new ArrayList<>();
18
19    List<Integer> negNums = new ArrayList<>();
20    List<Integer> posNums = new ArrayList<>();
21    boolean zeroExists = false;
22
23    for (int n:nums) {
24        if (n>=0) {
25            posNums.add(n);
26        } else {
27            negNums.add(n);
28        }
29    }
30
31    Set<Integer> done = new HashSet<>();
32    // 1 pos, 2 neg case
33    for (int posN:posNums) {
34        if (!done.contains(posN) && posN!=0) {
35            this.newTwoSum(negNums,-posN,res);
36            done.add(posN);
37        }
38    }
39    done.clear();
40    // 1 neg, 2 pos case
41    for (int negN:negNums) {
42        if (!done.contains(negN)) {
43            this.newTwoSum(posNums,-negN,res);
44            done.add(negN);
45        }
46    }
47
48    if (Collections.frequency(posNums, Integer.valueOf(0))>=3) {
49        res.add(new ArrayList<Integer>(Arrays.asList(0,0,0)));
50    }
51
52    return res;
53}
Remarks and Complexity Analysis:

  • The solution is suboptimal as it handles edge cases and some scenarios separately rather than seamlessly under one logical framework.

  • When I decided to implement the O(n^2) solution (or anything more than O(nlogn)), I should have immediately thought about sorting and making the algorithm more efficient after sorting.

  • Time Complexity: O(n^2) where n=nums.length

  • Space Complexity: O(n)

Cleaner solution:

 1public List<List<Integer>> threeSum(int[] num) {
 2    Arrays.sort(num);
 3    List<List<Integer>> res = new LinkedList<>();
 4    for (int i = 0; i < num.length-2; i++) {
 5        if (i == 0 || (i > 0 && num[i] != num[i-1])) {
 6            int lo = i+1, hi = num.length-1, sum = 0 - num[i];
 7            while (lo < hi) {
 8                if (num[lo] + num[hi] == sum) {
 9                    res.add(Arrays.asList(num[i], num[lo], num[hi]));
10                    while (lo < hi && num[lo] == num[lo+1]) lo++;
11                    while (lo < hi && num[hi] == num[hi-1]) hi--;
12                    lo++; hi--;
13                } else if (num[lo] + num[hi] < sum) lo++;
14                else hi--;
15        }
16        }
17    }
18    return res;
19}

Day 33 [19 Mar]

Question 55: Remove Nth Node From End of List

Given the head of a linked list, remove the nth node from the end of the list and return its head.

My Two-traversal solution:

 1public ListNode removeNthFromEnd(ListNode head, int n) {
 2    // determine length of list
 3    int length = 1;
 4    ListNode curr = head;
 5    while (curr.next!=null) {
 6        curr = curr.next;
 7        length++;
 8    }
 9    if (length==1) {
10        return null;
11    } else if (length==n) {
12        return head.next;
13    } else {
14        curr = head;
15        for (int i=0;i<length-n-1;i++) {
16            curr=curr.next;
17        }
18        curr.next = curr.next.next;
19        return head;
20    }
21}

My One Traversal solution:

 1public ListNode removeNthFromEnd(ListNode head, int n) {
 2    int length = 1;
 3    ListNode curr = head;
 4    Map<Integer,ListNode> idxToNode = new HashMap<>();
 5    while (curr.next!=null) {
 6        idxToNode.put(length-1,curr);
 7        curr = curr.next;
 8        length++;
 9    }
10    if (length==1) {
11        return null;
12    } else if (length==n) {
13        return head.next;
14    } else {
15        ListNode nodeBefore = idxToNode.get(length-n-1);
16        nodeBefore.next = nodeBefore.next.next;
17        return head;
18    }
19}
Remarks and Complexity Analysis:

  • The question was quite simple compared to the difficulty indicated

  • Thinking about the time complexity of the solution I am considering gave me more confidence that I am doing the right thing (i.e. most efficient possible)

  • Time Complexity: both. O(n) where n=list.size

  • Space Complexity: two-traversal. O(1) one-traversal. O(n)

Really creative solution that reduces space complexity to O(1):

 1public ListNode removeNthFromEnd(ListNode head, int n) {
 2
 3    ListNode start = new ListNode(0);
 4    ListNode slow = start, fast = start;
 5    start.next = head;
 6
 7    //Move fast in front so that the gap between slow and fast becomes n
 8    for(int i=1; i<=n+1; i++)   {
 9        fast = fast.next;
10    }
11    //Move fast to the end, maintaining the gap
12    while(fast != null) {
13        slow = slow.next;
14        fast = fast.next;
15    }
16    //Skip the desired node
17    slow.next = slow.next.next;
18    return start.next;
19}

The utility of creating a dummy head is that it can return an empty list without having to handle that case separately! It also helps manage indices :-)

Note

It seems that I am not utilizing even 20% of the full power that two-pointers support.

Day 34 [21 Mar]

Question 56: Search in Rotated Sorted Array

There is an integer array nums sorted in ascending order (with distinct values).

Prior to being passed to your function, nums is possibly rotated at an unknown pivot index k (1 <= k < nums.length) such that the resulting array is [nums[k], nums[k+1], …, nums[n-1], nums[0], nums[1], …, nums[k-1]] (0-indexed). For example, [0,1,2,4,5,6,7] might be rotated at pivot index 3 and become [4,5,6,7,0,1,2].

Given the array nums after the possible rotation and an integer target, return the index of target if it is in nums, or -1 if it is not in nums.

You must write an algorithm with O(log n) runtime complexity.

My solution:

 1public int search(int[] nums, int target) {
 2    int nLen = nums.length;
 3    int lo = 0;
 4    int hi = nLen-1;
 5
 6    // locate pivot/minimum - O(log n)
 7    while (lo<hi) {
 8        int mid = (hi+lo)/2;
 9        if (nums[mid]<nums[hi]) {
10            hi = mid;
11        } else {
12            // nums[mid] is greater than at least one thing so...
13            lo = mid+1;
14        }
15    }
16    // binary search for target - adjusting for circular array
17    int pivot = lo;
18    lo = 0;
19    hi = nLen-1;
20    while (lo<=hi) {
21        int mid = (hi+lo)/2;
22        int adjMid = (mid+pivot)%nLen;
23        if (nums[adjMid]==target) {
24            return adjMid;
25        } else if (nums[adjMid]<target) {
26            lo = mid+1;
27        } else {
28            hi = mid-1;
29        }
30    }
31    return -1;
32}
Remarks and Complexity Analysis:

  • This question took me way too much time.

  • I was trying to implement a O(log n) solution that would use very close to exactly log n operations, rather than the ~2 log n operation solution (seen above). It was complicated and difficult to implement. Understanding the growth of functions, if I can prove that a method has a certain big-O time, I should be not linger and struggle in attempt to reduce the constant factor.

  • Time Complexity: O(log n) where n=nums.length

  • Space Complexity: O(1)

// attempt stopped in progress
public int search(int[] nums, int target) {
        int numsLen = nums.length;
        int[] lo = new int[] {0, nums[0]}; // idx & value
        int[] hi = new int[] {numsLen/2, nums[numsLen/2]};

        if (lo[1]==target) {
            return lo[0];
        } else if (hi[1]==target) {
            return hi[0];
        }

        int[] cand = new int[] {-1, target-1};

        while (cand[1]!=target) {
            if (lo[1]<hi[1]) { // ascending
                if (lo[1]<target && hi[1]>target) {
                    cand[0] =
                }
            }
        }

    }

// similar idea but completed
public int search(int[] A, int target) {
    int lo = 0;
    int hi = A.length - 1;
    while (lo < hi) {
        int mid = (lo + hi) / 2;
        if (A[mid] == target) return mid;

        if (A[lo] <= A[mid]) {
            if (target >= A[lo] && target < A[mid]) {
                hi = mid - 1;
            } else {
                lo = mid + 1;
            }
        } else {
            if (target > A[mid] && target <= A[hi]) {
                lo = mid + 1;
            } else {
                hi = mid - 1;
            }
        }
    }
    return A[lo] == target ? lo : -1;
}

Question 57: Spiral Matrix

Given an m x n matrix, return all elements of the matrix in spiral order.

Solution:

  1public List<Integer> spiralOrder(int[][] matrix) {
  2
  3    List<Integer> res = new ArrayList<Integer>();
  4
  5    if (matrix.length == 0) {
  6        return res;
  7    }
  8
  9    int rowBegin = 0;
 10    int rowEnd = matrix.length-1;
 11    int colBegin = 0;
 12    int colEnd = matrix[0].length - 1;
 13
 14    while (rowBegin <= rowEnd && colBegin <= colEnd) {
 15        // Traverse Right
 16        for (int j = colBegin; j <= colEnd; j ++) {
 17            res.add(matrix[rowBegin][j]);
 18        }
 19        rowBegin++;
 20
 21        // Traverse Down
 22        for (int j = rowBegin; j <= rowEnd; j ++) {
 23            res.add(matrix[j][colEnd]);
 24        }
 25        colEnd--;
 26
 27        if (rowBegin <= rowEnd) {
 28            // Traverse Left
 29            for (int j = colEnd; j >= colBegin; j --) {
 30                res.add(matrix[rowEnd][j]);
 31            }
 32        }
 33        rowEnd--;
 34
 35        if (colBegin <= colEnd) {
 36            // Traver Up
 37            for (int j = rowEnd; j >= rowBegin; j --) {
 38                res.add(matrix[j][colBegin]);
 39            }
 40        }
 41        colBegin ++;
 42    }
 43    return res;
 44}
 45
 46// faulty attempt
 47public List<Integer> spiralOrder(int[][] matrix) {
 48    List<Integer> res = new ArrayList<Integer>();
 49    if (matrix==null || matrix.length==0) {
 50        return res;
 51    }
 52
 53    int x_i, x_f, y_i, y_f;
 54    x_i = y_i = 0;
 55    x_f = matrix[0].length-1;
 56    y_f = matrix.length-1;
 57    while (x_i<=x_f || y_i<=y_f) {
 58        // top left -> top right
 59        for (int i = x_i; i <= x_f; i++) {
 60            res.add(matrix[y_i][i]);
 61            // System.out.println("here1");
 62        }
 63        y_i++;
 64        // right top -> right bottom
 65        for (int i = y_i; i <= y_f; i++) {
 66            res.add(matrix[i][x_f]);
 67            // System.out.println("here22");
 68        }
 69        x_f--;
 70        // bottom right -> bottom left
 71        if (y_i<=y_f) {
 72            for (int i = x_f; i >= x_i ; i--) {
 73                res.add(matrix[y_f][i]);
 74                // System.out.println("here3");
 75            }
 76        }
 77        y_f--;
 78        // left bottom -> left top
 79        if (x_i<=x_f) {
 80            for (int i = y_f; i >= y_i; i--) {
 81                res.add(matrix[i][x_i]);
 82                // System.out.println("here4");
 83            }
 84        }
 85        x_i++;
 86    }
 87    return res;
 88}
 89
 90// Another solution
 91public List<Integer> spiralOrder(int[][] matrix) {
 92    List<Integer> res = new LinkedList<>();
 93    if (matrix == null || matrix.length == 0) return res;
 94    int n = matrix.length, m = matrix[0].length;
 95    int up = 0,  down = n - 1;
 96    int left = 0, right = m - 1;
 97    while (res.size() < n * m) {
 98        for (int j = left; j <= right && res.size() < n * m; j++)
 99            res.add(matrix[up][j]);
100
101        for (int i = up + 1; i <= down - 1 && res.size() < n * m; i++)
102            res.add(matrix[i][right]);
103
104        for (int j = right; j >= left && res.size() < n * m; j--)
105            res.add(matrix[down][j]);
106
107        for (int i = down - 1; i >= up + 1 && res.size() < n * m; i--)
108            res.add(matrix[i][left]);
109
110        left++; right--; up++; down--;
111    }
112    return res;
113}
Remarks and Complexity Analysis:

  • Had a difficult time with this…

  • Time Complexity: O(n) where n=total_elements

  • Space Complexity: O(1)

Day 35 [22 Mar]

Question 58: Jump Game

You are given an integer array nums. You are initially positioned at the array’s first index, and each element in the array represents your maximum jump length at that position.

Return true if you can reach the last index, or false otherwise.

My Solution:

 1private Map<Integer,Boolean> memo = new HashMap<>();
 2
 3public boolean canJumpHelper(int[] nums, int currIdx) {
 4    if (this.memo.containsKey(currIdx)) {
 5        return memo.get(currIdx);
 6    }
 7    if (currIdx + nums[currIdx] >= nums.length-1) {
 8        this.memo.put(currIdx,true);
 9        return true;
10    } else if (nums[currIdx]<=0 && currIdx<nums.length-1) {
11        this.memo.put(currIdx,false);
12        return false;
13    } else {
14        boolean res = false;
15        for (int i=1; i<=nums[currIdx] && (!res); i++) {
16            if (this.memo.containsKey(currIdx+i) && !this.memo.get(currIdx+i)) {
17                continue;
18            }
19            res = res || this.canJumpHelper(nums,currIdx+i);
20        }
21        this.memo.put(currIdx,res);
22        return res;
23    }
24}
25
26public boolean canJump(int[] nums) {
27    return this.canJumpHelper(nums,0);
28}

Unfortunately, this code got me a 169 / 169 test cases passed, but took too long error.

Here is an O(n) solution:

 1public boolean canJump(int[] nums) {
 2    int dis = 0;
 3    for (int i = 0; i <= dis; i++) {
 4        dis = Math.max(dis, i + nums[i]);
 5        if (dis >= nums.length-1) {
 6            return true;
 7        }
 8    }
 9    return false;
10}

My O(n) adapted solution (next day):

 1public boolean canJump(int[] nums) {
 2    int reach = 0;
 3    for (int i=0; i<=reach && reach<nums.length-1; i++) {
 4        reach = Math.max(nums[i]+i,reach);
 5    }
 6    if (reach>=nums.length-1) {
 7        return true;
 8    } else {
 9        return false;
10    }
11}
Remarks and Complexity Analysis:

  • Takeaway = don’t think too complex but also don’t think too simple… the balance is difficult to strike but I will get it someday!

  • Time Complexity: O(n) where n=nums.length

  • Space Complexity: O(1)

Question 59: Merge Intervals

Given an array of intervals where intervals[i] = [starti, endi], merge all overlapping intervals, and return an array of the non-overlapping intervals that cover all the intervals in the input.

Solution:

 1public int[][] merge(int[][] intervals) {
 2    if (intervals.length==1) {
 3        return intervals;
 4    }
 5
 6    // sort by starting point
 7    Arrays.sort(intervals, (i1,i2) -> Integer.compare(i1[0], i2[0]));
 8
 9    List<int[]> res = new ArrayList<>();
10    int[] currIvl = intervals[0];
11
12    for (int[] ivl:intervals) {
13        if (ivl[0]<=currIvl[1]) { // overlap found
14            currIvl[1] = Math.max(currIvl[1], ivl[1]);
15        } else {
16            res.add(currIvl);
17            currIvl = ivl;
18        }
19    }
20    res.add(currIvl);
21
22    return res.toArray(new int[res.size()][]);
23}
24
25// second time (next day)
26public int[][] merge(int[][] intervals) {
27    // sort intervals by fst
28    Arrays.sort(intervals, (i1,i2) -> Integer.compare(i1[0], i2[0]));
29
30    List<int[]> res = new ArrayList<>();
31
32    int[] currIvl=intervals[0];
33    for (int[] ivl : intervals) {
34        if (ivl[0]<=currIvl[1]) {
35            currIvl[1] = Math.max(currIvl[1], ivl[1]);
36        } else {
37            res.add(currIvl);
38            currIvl = ivl;
39        }
40    }
41    res.add(currIvl);
42
43    return res.toArray(new int[res.size()][]);
44}

Note

For complex problems that you know cannot be solved in O(n), consider using SORT. It could be incredibly helpful!

Remarks and Complexity Analysis:

  • I am starting to (mildly and jokingly) dislike my brain. It is really tough to come up with solutions to these questions.

  • Time Complexity: O(nlogn) where n=intervals.length

  • Space Complexity: O(1) apart from the returned array

Day 36 [23 Mar]

Question 60: Rotate Image

You are given an n x n 2D matrix representing an image, rotate the image by 90 degrees (clockwise).

You have to rotate the image in-place, which means you have to modify the input 2D matrix directly. DO NOT allocate another 2D matrix and do the rotation.

My solution:

 1public void rotate(int[][] matrix) {
 2    int n = matrix.length;
 3    int start = 0;
 4    int end = n-1;
 5    for (int i=0;i<(Math.ceil(n/2.0));i++) { // all rows till center is visited
 6        for (int j=start;j<end;j++) {
 7            int currI = i;
 8            int currJ = j;
 9            int prevVal = matrix[currI][currJ];
10            do {
11                int tmp = matrix[currJ][n-1-currI];
12                matrix[currJ][n-1-currI] = prevVal;
13                prevVal = tmp;
14                int tmpI = currI;
15                currI = currJ;
16                currJ = n-1-tmpI;
17            } while (!(currI==i && currJ==j));
18        }
19        start++;
20        end--;
21    }
22}
Remarks and Complexity Analysis:

  • It really helped to write down the change of indices of a test case and observe the pattern (rather than just thinking about it).

  • Struggled with implementing the non-atomic swap operations

  • Time Complexity: O(n) where n=matrix.length * matrix[0].length = numOfElements

  • Space Complexity: O(1)

Genius (C++) solution found on LeetCode:

 1/*
 2* clockwise rotate
 3* first reverse up to down, then swap the symmetry
 4* 1 2 3     7 8 9     7 4 1
 5* 4 5 6  => 4 5 6  => 8 5 2
 6* 7 8 9     1 2 3     9 6 3
 7*/
 8void rotate(vector<vector<int> > &matrix) {
 9    reverse(matrix.begin(), matrix.end());
10    for (int i = 0; i < matrix.size(); ++i) {
11        for (int j = i + 1; j < matrix[i].size(); ++j)
12            swap(matrix[i][j], matrix[j][i]);
13    }
14}
15
16/*
17* anticlockwise rotate
18* first reverse left to right, then swap the symmetry
19* 1 2 3     3 2 1     3 6 9
20* 4 5 6  => 6 5 4  => 2 5 8
21* 7 8 9     9 8 7     1 4 7
22*/
23void anti_rotate(vector<vector<int> > &matrix) {
24    for (auto vi : matrix) reverse(vi.begin(), vi.end());
25    for (int i = 0; i < matrix.size(); ++i) {
26        for (int j = i + 1; j < matrix[i].size(); ++j)
27            swap(matrix[i][j], matrix[j][i]);
28    }
29}

In Java:

 1public void rotate(int[][] matrix) {
 2    int s = 0, e = matrix.length - 1;
 3    while(s < e){
 4        int[] temp = matrix[s];
 5        matrix[s] = matrix[e];
 6        matrix[e] = temp;
 7        s++; e--;
 8    }
 9
10    for(int i = 0; i < matrix.length; i++){
11        for(int j = i+1; j < matrix[i].length; j++){
12            int temp = matrix[i][j];
13            matrix[i][j] = matrix[j][i];
14            matrix[j][i] = temp;
15        }
16    }
17}

Question 61: Set Matrix Zeros

Given an m x n integer matrix matrix, if an element is 0, set its entire row and column to 0’s.

You must do it in place. Could you devise a constant space solution?

My solution:

 1// Naive O(mn) space solution
 2public void setZeroes(int[][] matrix) {
 3    List<int[]> originalZeros = new ArrayList<>();
 4
 5    for (int i=0; i<matrix.length; i++) {
 6        for (int j=0; j<matrix[0].length; j++) {
 7            if (matrix[i][j]==0) {
 8                originalZeros.add(new int[] {i,j});
 9            }
10        }
11    }
12    for (int[] coord:originalZeros) {
13        for (int c=0; c<matrix.length; c++) {
14            matrix[c][coord[1]] = 0;
15        }
16        for (int d=0; d<matrix[0].length; d++) {
17            matrix[coord[0]][d] = 0;
18        }
19    }
20}
21
22// Less Naive O(m+n) space solution
23public void setZeroes(int[][] matrix) {
24    Set<Integer> R = new HashSet<>();
25    Set<Integer> C = new HashSet<>();
26
27    for (int i=0; i<matrix.length; i++) {
28        for (int j=0; j<matrix[0].length; j++) {
29            if (matrix[i][j]==0) {
30                R.add(i);
31                C.add(j);
32            }
33        }
34    }
35    for (int i=0; i<matrix.length; i++) {
36        for (int j=0; j<matrix[0].length; j++) {
37            if (R.contains(i) || C.contains(j)) {
38                matrix[i][j] = 0;
39            }
40        }
41    }
42}
Remarks and Complexity Analysis:

  • Pretty simple question (haven’t said that in a while)

  • Time Complexity: O(m * n) as all elements in the matrix is traversed (twice)

  • Space Complexity: O(m+n) - by using HashSet, we limit the number of entries in R to m and C to n. The Naive solution has a upper limit (worst case) big-O space complexity of O(m*n)

LeetCode’s O(1) space solution:

 1public void setZeroes(int[][] matrix) {
 2    Boolean isCol = false;
 3    int R = matrix.length;
 4    int C = matrix[0].length;
 5
 6    for (int i = 0; i < R; i++) {
 7
 8      // Since first cell for both first row and first column is the same i.e. matrix[0][0]
 9      // We can use an additional variable for either the first row/column.
10      // For this solution we are using an additional variable for the first column
11      // and using matrix[0][0] for the first row.
12      if (matrix[i][0] == 0) {
13        isCol = true;
14      }
15
16      for (int j = 1; j < C; j++) {
17        // If an element is zero, we set the first element of the corresponding row and column to 0
18        if (matrix[i][j] == 0) {
19          matrix[0][j] = 0;
20          matrix[i][0] = 0;
21        }
22      }
23    }
24
25    // Iterate over the array once again and using the first row and first column, update the elements.
26    for (int i = 1; i < R; i++) {
27      for (int j = 1; j < C; j++) {
28        if (matrix[i][0] == 0 || matrix[0][j] == 0) {
29          matrix[i][j] = 0;
30        }
31      }
32    }
33
34    // See if the first row needs to be set to zero as well
35    if (matrix[0][0] == 0) {
36      for (int j = 0; j < C; j++) {
37        matrix[0][j] = 0;
38      }
39    }
40
41    // See if the first column needs to be set to zero as well
42    if (isCol) {
43      for (int i = 0; i < R; i++) {
44        matrix[i][0] = 0;
45      }
46    }
47}
